title-group.article-title: On the piercing force enhancement of aluminum foam sandwich plates under impact loading

article-meta.aff: Laboratoire de Mécanique et Technologie, ENS Cachan/CNRS UMR8535/UPMC/PRES UniverSud Paris, 61, Avenue du président wilson, 94235 Cachan cedex, France.

author-notes.corresp: H Zhao, Laboratoire de Mécanique et Technologie, ENS Cachan/CNRS UMR8535/UPMC/PRES UniverSud Paris, 61, Avenue du président wilson, 94235 Cachan cedex, France Email: zhao@lmt.ens-cachan.fr

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This article tends to explain the observed piercing force enhancement under impact loading of the sandwich panels, which is made of rate-insensitive aluminum skin sheet and Cymat foam core. Using an elastic–plastic damageable model for the skin and an isotropic foam constitutive model for the core, a numerical model is proposed and validated by the comparison with experimental results. Virtual tests allow revealing that the damage evolution in the skin sheet is strain rate dependent because of the wave propagation effects. Under impact loading, the damage area is larger and it leads to a larger deflection of the skin plate at its breaking. Therefore, the foam cores are more compressed under impact loading and induce the piercing force enchancement of the sandwich.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Sandwich plates with cellular core are widely used in aeronautical applications for the impact energy absorption. For example, such sandwich panels are used to protect the airplane cockpit against bird strikes [1,2]. An interesting issue is to study their piercing behavior under impact loading and a number of experimental works are reported in the open literatures [3–9]. Some analytical works in the literature studied the piercing process [10,11] and the piercing force was found depending on the failure strength of the skin and on the flow stress of the core.

Recently, a new experimental method based on Hopkinson pressure bar was developed to accurately record the piercing force time history during the whole perforation process [12]. In this experiment, the sandwich sample launched by a gas gun strikes the perforator consisting of a long instrumented Hopkinson bar (diameter 16 mm) with a semi-spherical nose at its perforating end. With this experimental set-up, a 60-mm diameter sandwich specimen made from two 0.8-mm thick 2024 T3 aluminum skins and a 40-mm thick Cymat aluminum foam core (AlSi7Mg0.5) was tested at an impact velocity of 45 m/s. The results showed a noticeable increase of the top skin-piercing force [12], which is rather surprising because the 2024 T3 aluminum sheet is known to be rate insensitive [13], and the Cymat aluminum (AlSi7Mg0.5) foam core is also proved to be rate insensitive [14]. Typical experimental results will be recalled in the following section but the detailed experimental features will not be repeated here to be concise. As a summary, the observed enhancement of the top skin-piercing force is real and it is not due to the apparent rate sensitivity of the basic components (skin or foam core).

This article aimed at understanding this puzzling force enhancement. As there is no possibility to obtain more detailed testing evidence, the numerical simulation is used to investigate the possible component interaction difference between quasi-static and impact cases (which is believed to be the reason for this observed enhancement). For this purpose, a numerical model is built and calibrated with testing results. The good agreement between testing and simulated results shows that this numerical model contains the main features of the perforation of the top skin. Afterwards, the validated numerical model is used to perform virtual tests at various impact velocities and local information not experimentally available (the damage evolution in top skin, the equivalent stress in foam core, etc.) are analyzed in order to better understand the piercing process. Finally, a simple model is proposed to provide a plausible explanation of this force enhancement.

sec.title: Numerical model for the perforation of sandwich plates
Numerical model for perforation of aluminum sheet only
sec.p:
The numerical model is defined on the explicit code Ls-Dyna (Ls-971 version) [15]. First of all, the simulation of piercing test of the aluminum 2024 T3 sheet only is performed, using a numerical model consisting of three parts, as shown in Figure 1. It is noticed that the axis-symmetrical model was not chosen because the experimentally observed fractures were not axis-symmetric. Figure 1.
Numerical model for aluminum sheet perforation.

This model consists of 8914 nodes, 5052 brick elements, and 3200 shell elements. The aluminum 2024 T3 sheets were represented by shell elements with five integration points in the thickness. The element size of 0.7 mm in the central contact region is chosen as a means of compromise between the calculating cost and the accuracy, adjusted by a number of preliminary simulations with various mesh sizes (no significant mesh dependence was observed). Automatic surface-to-surface contact is applied in the entire contacting surfaces. In particular, the friction between the aluminum sheet and the perforators is supposed to be negligible, because the surface is lubricated in the test. In order to check the influence of this assumption, simulations with different friction coefficients are performed and the no-friction condition was very close to the experiment.

The support and the perforator are represented as the rigid body by the material type 20 *(MAT_RIGID) in Ls-Dyna codes. As the material model of type 154 *(MAT_DESHPANDE_FLECK_FOAM) used for the foam core is not available in implicit version, the quasi-static simulation is realized with the ‘mass scaling’ method (with a negligible kinetic energy). The boundary condition in the quasi-static simulation is as follows: the support is fixed in all degrees of freedom and the perforator pushes with a constant velocity of 0.1 mm/s. For the impact simulation, the velocity directly measured from the experiments is prescribed to the support together with aluminum sheet. The contact between sheet and support is defined as tied.

The behavior of the skin sheet is modeled by a damageable isotropic hardening elastic–plastic constitutive law proposed by Lemaitre [16], available in Ls-Dyna as the model of type 104 (MAT_DAMAGE_1). It is the only existing ductile damage model, already used for 2024 T3 sheet in the impact simulations [2]. Such an isotropic damage model proposes a relationship between effective stress and the damage accumulated plastic strain r, moderated by the isotropic damage variable D(0 ≤ D ≤ 1) (1)

The evolution rule of the damage variable is defined as (2) where the rate of the damage accumulated plastic strain r is related to the accumulated plastic strainɛ·pl withr·=(1-D)ɛ·pl, rD the threshold for damage initiation, S a positive material constant, andy¯ the strain energy density release rate defined by Equation (3) (3) where σvm is the von Mises stress, σH the hydrostatic pressure, εe the elastic strain, Rν the tri-axiality coefficient, and ν the Poisson’s ratio. We notice that the fracture criterion is defined by a critical damage value Dc in this isotropic damage model and there is no strain rate effect.

The parameters used for 2024 T3 aluminum sheet were identified from normalized tension tests [2,17], and are given in Table 1. Table 1.
Identified parameters of isotropic damage model
Parameters Value
ρ 2700 kg/m3
E 70 GPa
v 0.3
Q1 222.7 MPa
Q2 0 MPa
C1 6.3798
C2 0
rD 0.23
S 0.5 MPa
Dc 0.6

A comparison between experimental tensile stress–plastic strain relation and that calculated from the identified model is shown in Figure 2. Figure 2.
Identification of 2024 T3 sheet.

As a validation, Figure 3 shows, respectively, the experimental (a) and numerical (b), the piercing force/displacement curves of aluminum sheet under quasi-static and dynamic loading. The main feature of the piercing process is well simulated and there is no noticeable force enhancement as expected (less than 150 N). One can also note that the oscillation in dynamic piercing force–displacement curve due to wave propagation effect is also well represented. Such comparison proves that the present numerical model is quite acceptable. Figure 3.
Piercing force–displacement curve of 0.8 mm 2024 T3 sheet: (a) experiments and (b) simulations.

sec.title: Numerical model of the sandwich Cymat perforation
sec.p:
The complete numerical sandwich model with foam cores consists of five parts (Figure 4). The sandwich panel is composed of two skins of aluminum 2024 T3 modeled, as above, and the foam core modeled using brick elements. This model consists of 245,146 nodes, 229,052 brick elements, and 6400 shell elements. As the most important zone is the penetration area just under the perforator, the foam cores located within the first 10 mm from the top skin are modeled with a fine mesh with 128,000 brick elements, which is four times as dense as in the rest part of the foam core. Figure 4.
Numerical model of sandwich perforation.

The behavior of the core is represented by the material model of type 154 (MAT_DESHPANDE_FLECK_FOAM), which gives the relation between an equivalent stress and an equivalent strain depending on a criterion shape parameter α [18]. The relation between equivalent stress and strain available in Ls-Dyna is an empirical one (Equation (4)) with several parameters to be determined [19]. (4) where σpl is the flow stress, εD the locking strain, and r, α2, and β the parameters of the model. Finally, the parameters of this model, given in Table 2, are identified using uni-axial compression testing results. Table 2.
Identified parameters of Fleck model
Parameters Value
ρ 235 kg/m3
E 250 MPa
v 0.05
σpl 3.9828 MPa
γ 0.95 MPa
α2 21.22 MPa
β 9.2
εD 0.8

The quality of this identification is shown on a compression test result given in Figure 5. Figure 5.
Simulated uni-axial compression curves compared with the experiment.

As a validation, Figure 6 (left) shows the simulated piercing force–displacement curve at 44 m/s compared with the experimental result. It can be seen that the simulation catches the main features till the top skin failure. The simulation is not accurate once the perforator goes into the foam core because the used isotropic foam model cannot represent the foam core behavior under an important shear component, and the erosion rule is on the basis of tensile strain. It is noticed that this point is not the focus of this article. Indeed, such a model did not permit to simulate the perforation of the foam core alone neither [2]. As for the simulation of aluminum sheet alone, the quasi-static perforation of sandwich plate is also performed using ‘mass scaling’ technique. Similar conclusion as the case under impact loading can be found (Figure 6, right). Figure 6.
Comparison between the experiment and simulation under dynamic loading.

However, as the aim is the force enhancement of top skin under impact loading, present simulation work is rather acceptable for this range of loading. Indeed, for this initial stage of perforation (<10 mm displacement around the top skin breaking), the calculated top skin breaking ‘petal’ shape is also close to the experimental breaking shape (Figure 7). Figure 7.
Breaking ‘petal’ shape by simulation and by post mortem observation.

It shows that these petals are not symmetric, and one petal is bigger than the others because the first failure/fracture is located at about 2–3 mm from the center. It is noted that there is no special treatment for this initial breaking point in simulation and the mesh is rather symmetric and regular. It proves that this simulation is quite reliable.

sec.title: Analysis of virtual numerical tests
sec.p:
The present numerical model was used to perform the virtual tests, where all the detailed information not available in a real test (strain, stress, etc.) are known. First of all, three numerical tests are conducted in the range from quasi-static (0.1 mm/s) to dynamic loading up to the impact velocity reached during the experiment (10 and 40 m/s). The results are given in Figure 8. It is observed that the piercing peak force regularly increases with the impact speed (Figure 9). It indicates that this model probably contains the hints for the understanding of this force enhancement, which is probably due to component interaction because the constitutive relations used for the foam cores as well as aluminum sheets are all rate insensitive. Figure 8.
The numerical result at 0.1 mm/s, 10 m/s, and 40 m/s. Figure 9.
Piercing peak force at different speeds: 0.1 mm/s, 10 m/s, and 40 m/s.

In order to understand this piercing force enhancement, any difference of detailed local information between static and dynamic loading is interesting. First of all, it is found that the maximum displacement of the top skin before breaking increases with the impact velocity. Figure 10 shows the displacement profiles of nodes located in a diametrical line at the exact time step when the top skin breaking occurs (D > Dc). Such an increase in the maximal perforation depth will lead to a larger contacting surface, where the foam core is compressed, and will hopefully lead to an enhanced strength of the sandwich. Figure 10.
The profile of the top skin at the moment of the first peak.

Thus, the key point is to understand why this displacement increases under impact loading. For this purpose, we try to check the plastic strain inside the plate, because a larger global displacement means a bigger plastic strain somewhere inside the top skin. As the strain and stress state are rather symmetric before skin breaking, half of 60 elements in a diameter direction is studied. Actually, only six elements close to the center are in contact with the perforator, and the strain is mainly concentrated in this area.

The accumulated plastic strain evolution under quasi-static loading is depicted in Figure 11(a), where the abscissa is the perforation depth and the ordinate is the element number (no°1 being on the center of the plate and no°30 at the edge of the skin), and the accumulated plastic strain is given in the gray level. The accumulated plastic strain at 44 m/s is shown in Figure 11(b). The increase in plastic strain under dynamic loading is observed in this contact area, which is consistent with the depth increase. Further looking inside reveals a difference of damage states between static and impact loading rates. Figure 11.
The accumulated plastic strain evolution under quasi-static loading.

In Figure 12, the damage evolution is drawn using the same space-time representation. It shows that the damage is localized at the element no°3 under static loading (Figure 12(a)), whereas the damage is rather diffused under impact loading (Figure 12(b)), even though the maximal damage still lies in the element no°3. Figure 12.
The damage evolution D under quasi-static loading.

The damage in a larger area under impact loading instead of just a localized point in one element under static loading leads to a larger area being deformed and leads finally to an increase in the deflection of the top skin at breaking. Such difference is closely related to the wave propagation effect inside the aluminum sheet. Indeed, a round trip of the flexion wave takes 40 µs and the whole perforation of top skin at 44 m/s lasts about 160 µs. The time interval of damage process is around 50 µs. In this softening process due to damage, the wave propagation effect definitely plays a role in the damage evolution.

Another noticeable difference is the stress (or strain) level in the foam core. In particular, the equivalent stress as well (as equivalent strain) defined by the model of Deshpande and Fleck can be calculated from the simulated von Mises stress (or strain) and hydrostatic pressure (or strain). Results are shown in Figure 13. A significant increase in stress amplitude (about 15%) is found for impact loading case, due to the increase in strain induced by the increase in the piercing depth before skin breaking. The dot line at the stress of 4 MPa in Figure 13 (right) shows the yield stress level below which the foam core undergoes only an elastic strain. Figure 13.
Fleck model equivalent strain (a) and stress (b) at the moment of top skin breaking.

sec.title: Basic model of the impact piercing force enhancement
sec.p:
The mechanics of the piercing force enhancement is rather complex in the whole numerical model but can be explained with a basic model proposed in Figure 14. From above numerical testing results, two noticeable differences between quasi-static and impact tests are found. First one is a larger deflection of the top skin at breaking under impact loading because of a more diffused damage evolution closely related to the wave propagation inside the aluminum skin sheet. The second is that this additional deflection induces an additional compression of the foam core under impact loading, which is believed to be the origin of the enhancement. Figure 14.
Simplified model for analysis of top skin perforation.

A simple model is proposed to check if these two effects are enough to give a quantitative estimation of the force enhancement. First, it is assumed that the piercing force of the incident top skin Fp can be expressed as the sum of the piercing force of the skin plate Fplate and the resistance force of the foam core Ffoam (Equation (5)) (5)

The simplified model considered here is given in Figure 15. First, as the piercing force of the skin only is rate insensitive, the force Fplate is constant at breaking whatever the piercing velocity. However, the increase in impact velocity induces an increase in the deflection of the top skin (Figure 15, top left), which induces an increase in the reaction of the foam core (Figure 15, bottom left, depicted here as the equivalent Fleck stress). The figure shows that this increase is rather constant, and non-zero only in the area under the perforator. Figure 15.
Simplified description for the analysis of force enhancement.

Therefore, the increase in velocity involves an increase in the maximum deflection δd. It leads to an increase in the contact area between the skin and the compacted foam core region denoted by δS. Thus, the force enhancement can be calculated as follows: (6) where R is the perforator radius, H the maximum piercing depth before skin breaking, andσ∧ the equivalent stress in the foam. According to the simulation results, those values are the following: Hqs = 6.6 mm,σ∧qs = 5.8 MPa; Hdyn = 7.2 mm,σ∧dyn = 6.4 MPa.

This estimation of Equation (6) gives the force enhancement ΔF = 400 N, to be compared to the 600 N given by the numerical results plotted in Figure 9. The order of magnitude is correct and gives credit to the proposed mechanical description of the force enhancement.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, the numerical models of the inversed perforation test on sandwich plates made from 0.8 mm 2024 T3 aluminum skin and Cymat aluminum (AlSi7Mg0.5) foam core are developed. The good agreement between simulated force/displacement curves and deforming maps with experiments shows that the proposed models can catch the mean features of the perforation process of tested sandwich plates. This numerical model is afterwards used as a virtual testing tool, which allows the analysis of detailed local information that cannot be measured in a real test.

Two noticeable differences between quasi-static and impact loadings are found. One is the maximum deflection of aluminum skin plate at breaking, and another is the compression level of foam cores at this breaking instant. Under impact loading, the skin plate undergoes a larger strain in a larger area due to a diffused damage, which is closely related to the wave propagation effect inside the skin plate. It leads to a larger deflection of skin sheet and a deeper compression of the foam core in contact with the skin.
A simple model is proposed in order to explain the mechanism of this impact piercing force enhancement and it provides an acceptable quantitative estimation.

ack.p: The authors recognize and acknowledge the European network of Excellence, KMM-NoE, for the financial support of the presented work.
